question: Does the removal of reactive oxygen species by activated oncogenes increase genomic instability in leukemia cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The oncogenic BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase induces constitutive DNA damage in Philadelphia chromosome (Ph)-positive leukemia cells.
content.source_2: We find that BCR/ABL-induced reactive oxygen species (ROSs) cause chronic oxidative DNA damage resulting in double-strand breaks (DSBs) in S and G(2)/M cell cycle phases.
content.source_3: In Ph-positive leukemias, BCR/ABL activation was observed to upregulate antioxidant defenses that lower intracellular ROS, attenuating oxidative signaling and DNA damage checkpoints; the resulting replication stress and checkpoint slippage favor error-prone HRR and NHEJ, thereby increasing genomic instability.
